content.description:
This is a fun face climb on pretty old fixed gear. It could use a makeover.

A punchy couple of moves at the bottom are protected by a funky KB. Then a good bolt protects the crux perfectly. An ancient fixed nut and another piton guard the 5.11 moves to the top.

This has really great movement and it's a pretty chunk of stone.

You need to carry some cord and a few pieces to make an anchor at the top.
content.protection: Quickdraws and trad gear for an anchor at the top.
content.location:
It is around the corner from

Log Jam

.

content.description:
Gillett's old book has this listed with an estimated grade of 5.9 and the FA history as unknown/unclimbed. I'm sure someone has climbed this since his book was published?

If not, we did, and it was quite nice Â A few butterfly jams and a few fist jams make up the best part of the route.

Top out, and walk off the back side.
content.protection: Several #4 Camalots would sew it up. I placed some small gear in horizontals and got a #3 and #4 in.
content.location: It is right off of the trail. You can't miss it if you've made it here. There is a large fallen log in front of it as well, hence the name.

content.description:
Up the hill from

Trail of Sand

and

Log Jam

is another short route. It's only two bolts long, lol.

It gets a star for having a really badass heuco. The heuco is reminiscent of the best stone at Jurassic Park. Otherwise, it's a small overhang on jugs. I'd probably feel comfortable bouldering it out. The second bolt kind of blows, too.
content.protection: Two quickdraws and some cord/gear for an anchor.
content.location:
It is a few steps uphill from

Log Jam

and

Trail of Sand

.
